awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Managing epidemics in wildlife with acquired resistance
awd_abstract_narration:
Infectious diseases pose a serious threat to many wild animals. While vaccination is a successful tool against diseases of humans and livestock, it is rarely used to control wildlife diseases. This is partly because of a poor understanding of immunity in wild animals and its impact across a large population. This award will address these gaps in knowledge by studying the immunity acquired by frogs against a fungus, Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd). Bd infection has caused a severe decline in frog numbers around the world. Recent studies have shown that frogs exposed to dead Bd become resistant to future infection. They suggest that the immune system of frogs can be harnessed to fight Bd. This award combines mathematical theory with laboratory and field experiments to understand the correlates of acquired resistance to Bd in frogs and assess the potential for managing outbreaks in wild populations by stimulating acquired resistance to the fungus. Results of this study will facilitate the development and testing of a novel, widely applicable theory for the management of epidemics in wildlife. Consequently, this work will help to curb losses of biodiversity. Researchers will share their results with groups working on frog conservation and provide multi-disciplinary training to a diverse group of scientists. Computer-based teaching tools that illustrate wildlife disease management through vaccination will be developed and made publicly available.
 
There is poor understanding of acquired resistance in wild animals and a scarcity of theory underlying wildlife vaccination. These gaps in physiology and ecology will be addressed in the current research using amphibians and the chytrid fungus, Bd.  Bd is selected for study because this pathogen contributes to global amphibian declines and the recent discovery that amphibians acquire immunological resistance following exposure to dead Bd. This award integrates mathematical theory with laboratory and field experiments to i) characterize the acquisition and maintenance of Bd resistance across host life stages, ii) evaluate the immunological mechanisms responsible for individual resistance and whether their presence predicts population-level outcomes, iii) determine if resistance can be induced in wild populations, and iv) if so, can this alter epidemics and host persistence in a whole-ecosystem experiment populations - an outcome of broad significance for wildlife conservation. This project links immunological mechanisms and individual-level traits to population- and community-level disease outcomes. It advances fundamental knowledge of host-parasite interactions while helping to curb disease-driven worldwide losses of biodiversity. Results of this research will be disseminated to conservation partners to help limit the spread of chytridiomycosis. This research will facilitate the training of a diverse group of scientists in physiology, ecology, and mathematical biology. Computer modules that illustrate general and amphibian-specific outcomes of disease management via acquired immunity will be integrated into teaching and made publicly available.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
All organisms experience infectious diseases caused by pathogens and parasites. These diseases can harm individual hosts and threaten populations, thereby affecting biodiversity. Despite the high diversity of parasites that harm wildlife and the rapid rate of emergence of new parasites, ecologists and conservationists have few tools available to curb the spread of disease and protect biodiversity. This project focused on frogs and their fungal parasites. Amphibians are a globally distributed and highly diverse group of animals that are current facing a global decline in abundance and biodiversity, in part due to infection by a highly pathogenic fungus, nicknamed “Bd”. Recent studies had shown that individual frogs can be partially protected from infection by prophylactic topical exposure to Bd parasites that had been grown in culture and then sterilized by flash-freezing. This project better characterized this increase in resistance at the individual frog scale, used mathematical modeling to project how these individual-level trait changes would translate at the population level, and tested a prophylaxis intervention over two years in replicated ponds in northern California.

This project found further evidence that amphibians acquire partial protection from exposure to sterilized pathogens prior to challenge with the living, infectious agent. In one part of the project, the researchers found that this protective effect can occur across genetic backgrounds of the parasite – frogs exposed to sterilized pathogens from one strain of the parasite exhibited a large increase in resistance against a different strain of the parasite. This experiment raised an interested hypothesis that lower virulence strains of the parasite, i.e., those that typically cause less disease in their frog hosts, might generally be good candidates to induce a resistance response in frogs. In another part of the project, the researchers determined that the success of the prophylactic procedure depends on timing relative to challenge with the live parasite. Frogs that were treated prior to exposure to the live fungus demonstrated resistance against the parasite as had been seen before. However, frogs that were treated shortly after the parasite exhibited no benefit. This experiment demonstrated two important points. First, treatment of natural populations should ideally occur at times of year when infections are rare, such as just after birth pulses. Second, while post-infection treatment was not successful, it did not cause adverse effects on frog survival. Thus, the treatment continues to demonstrate high safety for frog hosts.

The project then developed simulation models of frog populations and fungal parasites in pond ecosystems to understand how these partially-protective effects for individuals might scale up to the population level. This analysis helped evaluate the feasibility of using this prophylaxis treatment as a conservation tool. This approach is similar to a vaccination campaign, so the researchers characterized these interventions with similar terminology: “coverage” described the proportion of the frog population that was treated, and “efficacy” described the strength of the treatment effect on the relevant trait. Because protection was partial, treated frogs could still become infected and the specific trait or process affected by the vaccine needed to be specified – (1) establishment of infection, (2) growth rate of parasite, (3) clearance or killing rate by the host, (4) mortality imposed by infection. The simulations determined that modest coverage of a prophylaxis that reduced establishment of infection could improve the persistence and abundance of frog populations. If the prophylaxis reduced parasite growth rate or increased clearance by hosts, then somewhat higher coverage was needed. Interestingly, if the prophylaxis partially reduced mortality caused by infection, then it could actually lead to even higher infection levels, which would then threaten population persistence, because frogs could develop massive infections and transmit high numbers of new parasites before finally dying. Thus, the study determined that the trait(s) affected by the treatment are critical determinants of success.

The project tested this prophylaxis intervention across 15 ponds in northern California. The treatment was applied to half of these sites just after the birth pulse and then metamorphosed frog were recovered at the end of the season and diagnosed for infections. Work by an REU-supported undergraduate demonstrated that this prophylaxis treatment did not have non-target effects on invertebrate biodiversity in these ponds. We are processing the final frog samples from these experiments now.

This project has relevance to other organisms and their pathogens. Partial protection from prophylaxis or vaccines is extremely common. Understanding the specific trait changes that occur can help develop effective interventions and anticipate backfire scenarios that might make outbreaks worse.

This project also integrated research with education, through the training of one postdoctoral scholar, one graduate student, and one undergraduate REU student (underrepresented minority). The researchers involved also founded the Emory chapter of the Wildlife Disease Association, established a seminar series for researchers and professionals in this field to present to undergraduates, and disseminated this research through journal articles and conference presentations.
